executive_summary: Crane rental companies have had ups and downs, as volatility in downstream markets has weakened the need for cranes. The pandemic hindered performance as most construction, mining and forestry markets saw slumps, reducing the need for cranes. Even so, low interest spurred an uptick in residential projects, which provided a small cushion for lessors. As the pandemic waned, interest rates spiked as inflationary concerns crept up, weakening residential construction. Even so, this prompted industrial and commercial contractors to resume previously deferred projects. The escalation in oil and gas prices increased drilling and extraction activity, contributing to revenue recovery post-pandemic. The advantages of renting are particularly beneficial for these sectors as it alleviates them from bearing the burdens of depreciation and maintenance costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Construction Markets Are in a Spiral
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Crane rentals had a tumultuous period stemming from economic shifts. Residential construction, which thrived amid the pandemic, began to contract as rising interest rates in 2022 and 2023 increased the cost of borrowing, leading to a slowdown in crane rentals and projects overall. Commercial construction encountered numerous challenges, pushing project timelines back amid economic uncertainty. It wasn't until 2023 that the sector regained footing, revealing signs of growth after enduring three years of sluggish performance.

Crane lessors incorporate technology into their operations to boost efficiency and reduce expenses. Online platforms offer a user-friendly interface, allowing potential customers to easily explore inventory, solicit quotes and rent equipment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Stabilization and Government Funding Pave the Way for Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The economy is set to stabilize as the Federal Reserve expects to cut rates down in 2024 as inflationary concerns wane. This will allow residential and nonresidential construction to rebound as contractors can take on more projects and rent cranes through favorable contracts. Rapidly deteriorating infrastructure in the US will fuel a need for cranes. The Bipartisan Infrastructure Law will continue to provide funding for various infrastructure projects through 2026.

The volatility of oil and gas prices can be a double-edged sword for crane rental companies. Because these prices can shift at any moment, miners will choose to rent to reduce risk. Even so, when prices are low, like the pandemic, lessors will see a drastic drop off in business as extraction activity weakens. While crude oil and natural gas prices spiked after the pandemic, they began to sink in 2023 and are set to slump through 2029, forcing extractors to cut down on excavations, leading to fewer crane rentals.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry rent out or lease cranes that may be used for

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Value of construction
threats: Low Outlier Growth - Yield on 10-year Treasury note

key_trends: It is hard for new entrants to join the industry because of high start-up costs. Lessors must purchase equipment upfront and hire skilled employees to handle all aspects of the service.
Buyers have more leverage in negotiations as most lessors follow competitive pricing. Lessors must ensure their equipment is working and current or risk losing clients.
While consolidation is low, it has continued to gain momentum. Larger lessors seek to acquire smaller local crane rental companies to expand their outreach.
Larger companies with adequate funds have an in-house fleet of cranes. Even so, companies prefer to rent since they do not have to worry about maintenance or depreciation costs.
Lower interest rates are set to improve performance throughout the outlook period. As concerns about inflation diminish, the Federal Reserve plans to initiate rate cuts beginning in 2024.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The construction market consists of residential, commercial and industrial projects. Construction projects rely on mobile and fixed cranes to help transport materials and assist on tall buildings.
Miners use cranes to help extract oil and gas and retrieve minerals from the earth. Cranes also help transport materials and assist with installing and replacing mining equipment.

The forestry sector uses cranes for various essential logging and timber processing tasks. Cranes make it easier to load logs onto trucks and trains for transportation. They also help lift and position heavy forestry equipment used during timber cutting.

products_and_services.product_description: Mobile cranes are mounted on a mobile platform (think trucks and crawlers), allowing them to quickly move to different locations. These cranes are designed for versatility and flexibility, making them suitable for various construction and industrial applications.
Fixed cranes are placed in one location and cannot be easily moved. These cranes are used in areas with consistent lifting requirements and do not require frequent repositioning.
Marine cranes are used in maritime and offshore environments. These cranes are installed on ships, vessels, offshore platforms and other marine structures to help lift and transport materials.

tier_1_suppliers: Construction Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Mining, Oil & Gas Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Specialized Storage & Warehousing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Apartment & Condominium Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Residential contractors specialize in constructing houses, apartment complexes, condominiums and executing remodeling projects. Cranes play a pivotal role in various facets of residential construction, facilitating the transportation of materials and contributing to the construction of tall buildings. When residential construction projects increase, so does the need for cranes, representing a potential opportunity for lessors.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region accounts for the largest share of establishments and population in the Crane Rental Services industry.
The Great Lakes region has the second largest share of establishments and population in the industry.
The Mid-Atlantic region ranks third in terms of industry establishments and population.
New England accounts for a small portion of industry establishments and population.
The Plains region has a moderate presence of industry establishments and population.
The Rocky Mountains region has a relatively small industry footprint in terms of establishments and population.
The Southwest accounts for a moderate share of industry establishments but a smaller population share.
The West region has the smallest presence of industry establishments and no population data is provided.

basis_points.basis_description: It is hard for new entrants to join the industry because of high start-up costs. Lessors must purchase equipment upfront and hire skilled employees to handle all aspects of the service.
Buyers have more leverage in negotiations as most lessors follow competitive pricing. Lessors must ensure their equipment is working and current or risk losing clients.
While consolidation is low, it has continued to gain momentum. Larger lessors seek to acquire smaller local crane rental companies to expand their outreach.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Size and Product Offerings Impact Profitability
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit can vary by the size and equipment offered by lessors. Some companies focus on a certain market or type of crane, while others have various options.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Labor Intensive Tasks Keep Wages Elevated
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Lessors depend on vigilant staff to manage operations and maintain cranes. Most companies also offer transportation services, assembly and disassembly of the crane.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Fluctuations in interest rates and the overall expense of borrowing can significantly impact revenue. With low interest rates, businesses tend to be more eager to undertake projects and engage in favorable lease agreements with lessors. As interest rates spike, companies find it more expensive to rent.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Numerous lessors are adopting user-friendly online platforms to facilitate crane rentals. These platforms simplify the rental procedure, enabling customers to explore the available equipment, place orders, communicate with support and oversee their rentals through online management.

FAQs.question: What are some key features offered by equipment rental companies?
FAQs.answer: Customers can explore available equipment, place orders, communicate with support and oversee their rentals through online management portals and mobile applications.

FAQs.question: How volatile are revenues in the equipment rental industry?
FAQs.answer: The industry experiences moderate revenue volatility.

FAQs.question: How do interest rates impact the equipment rental industry?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuations in interest rates and borrowing costs can significantly impact revenues. Low interest rates encourage businesses to rent equipment, while high rates make renting more expensive, though still cost-saving compared to ownership.

FAQs.question: What is the level of regulation in the equipment rental industry?
FAQs.answer: The industry faces moderate regulation that is increasing over time.

FAQs.question: How much assistance is available for the equipment rental industry?
FAQs.answer: The industry receives low and steady levels of assistance.
